columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to learn about equity as an option using Black Scholes Model and net present value.

To start with, let us define  Black Scholes Model. 

**Black Scholes Model** is a mathematical equation that involves probabilities to compute the price of an option. 

The equation of the Black Scholes Model is illustrated as follows: 

$$\textbf{C}=\text{S}\times\text{N}_{\text{(d1})}-\text{X}\times\text{e}^{\text{-rt}}\times\text{N}_{\text{(d2)}}$$

Where: 

- C- Call Option
- S- Stock Price
- X - Exercise Price
- r - rate
- t - time
- N(d1) - Probability if z is less than or equal to d1
- N(d2) - Probability if z is less than or equal to d2

The **net present value (NPV)** is the present value of initial investment or cash outflow less the present value of the cash inflows.

In investment decisions, the firm should choose the alternative with a higher net present value.

Whereas d1 is solved as follows: 

$$\textbf{d}_{1}=\frac{\left[\text{ln}\frac{\text{S}}{\text{X}}\right]+\left(\text{r}+\frac{σ^2}{2}\right)\times\text{t}}{\left(σ\times\sqrt{\text{t}}\right)}$$

And d2's equation is illustrated below: 

$$\textbf{d}_{2}=\text{d}_{1}-σ\times\sqrt{\text{t}}$$

Where: 

- σ - Standard deviation
- ln - natural logarithm

Here are the parameters to solve the problem : 


|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Market value of asset (S) |$15,900,000 | 
| Face value of debt (X) |$17,500,000 | 
|Risk-free rate (r) | 6% | 
|Time (t) |5 years | 
|Standard deviation(σ) | 41% per year| 
| e| 2.71828|

## Requirement A

We are asked to solve the current market value of the firm's equity.

Next, let us solve the natural logarithm of the quotient of the value of assets and the face value of debt. 

We are going to use excel to solve the natural logarithm. The formula should look as follows: 

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/0b69a6e6-ee45-4227-8299-d90c29e902da-1661850127615846.png)


Therefore ln(S/X) is -0.0959.

Now, we solve the value of d2 using the equation in Step 3: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{d}_{2}&=0.6810-0.41\times\sqrt{5}\\[15pt]
&=0.6810-0.41\times2.2361\\[15pt]
&=0.6810-0.9168\\[15pt]
&=-0.2358
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, the value of d2 is -0.2358.

Now, here are the values of N(d1) and N(d2) using the cumulative normal distribution table: 


|Normal distribution | | 
|--|--| 
|Nd1 |0.7518 | 
|Nd2 |0.4052 |

Using the equation in Step 2, the value of the call option is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{C}&=\$15,900,000\times0.7518-\$17,500,000\times2.71828^{-(0.06)(5)}\times0.4052\\[15pt]
&=\$15,900,000\times0.7518-\$17,500,000\times2.71828^{-(0.30)}\times0.4052\\[15pt]
&=\$15,900,000\times0.7518-\$17,500,000\times0.7408\times0.4052\\[15pt]
&=\$15,900,000\times0.7518-\$17,500,000\times0.3002\\[15pt]
&=\$11,953,620-\$5,253,500\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$6,700,120}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the value of the call option or the firm's equity is $6,311.

## Requirement B

We are asked to solve the current market value of the company's debt. 


The value of debt is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Debt}&=\text{Asset's Value}-\text{Equity}\\[15pt]
&=\$15,900,000-\$6,700,120\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$9,199,880}
\end{aligned}$$

The computed value of equity is deducted from the asset's value to determine the value of debt. 

Thus, the value of the debt is $9,199,880.

## Requirement C

We are asked to compute the company's cost of debt. 

The cost of debt is solved as follows. 

Let *r* be the cost of debt: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Value of debt}&=\text{Face value}\times\text{e}^{-\text{rt}}\\[15pt]
\$9,199,880&=\$17,500,000\times2.71828^{-\text{(r)}(5)}\\[15pt]
2.71828^{-\text{(r)}(5)}&=\frac{\$9,199,880}{\$17,500,000}\\[20pt]
2.71828^{-\text{(5r)}}&=0.5257\\[15pt]
\textbf{r}&=\boxed{0.1286\space\text{or}\space12.86\%}
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, the cost of debt is 12.86%.

## Requirement D

We are asked to solve the new market value of equity if the project has a net present value of $2,200,000. 

First, we have to solve the value of the asset using this equation. 

$$\textbf{Asset}=\text{MV of Firm's Assets}+\text{NPV of Project}$$

The market value of the firm's asset is added by the net present value of the project to determine the value of the asset of the particular project.

Using the equation in Step 14, the value of the asset of the new firm is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Asset}&=\$15,900,000+\$2,200,000\\[15pt]
&=\$18,100,000
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, the value of assets in the new firm is $18,100,000.

Next, let us solve the natural logarithm of the quotient of the value of assets and the face value of debt. 

We are going to use excel to solve the natural logarithm. The formula should look as follows: 

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/035ffb2d-6c84-46f4-9a70-42281d0f36d7-1661852801215977.png)


Therefore ln(S/X) is 0.0337.

Now, we solve the value of d2 using the equation in Step 3: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{d}_{2}&=0.8224-0.41\times\sqrt{5}\\[15pt]
&=0.8224-0.41\times2.2361\\[15pt]
&=0.8224-0.9168\\[15pt]
&=-0.0944
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, the value of d2 is -0.0944.

Now, here are the values of N(d1) and N(d2) using the cumulative normal distribution table: 


|Normal distribution | | 
|--|--| 
|Nd1 |0.7939 | 
|Nd2 |0.4642 |

## Requirement D

We are asked to solve the cost of debt of the new project.  

First, we will solve the value of debt: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Debt}&=\text{Asset's Value}-\text{Equity}\\[15pt]
&=\$18,100,000-\$8,351,340\\[15pt]
&=\$9,748,660
\end{aligned}$$

The computed value of equity is deducted from the asset's value to determine the value of debt. 

Thus, the value of the debt is $9,748,660.

The cost of debt is solved as follows. 

Let *r* be the cost of debt: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Value of debt}&=\text{Face value}\times\text{e}^{-\text{rt}}\\[15pt]
\$9,748,660&=\$17,500,000\times2.71828^{-\text{(r)}(5)}\\[15pt]
2.71828^{-\text{(r)}(5)}&=\frac{\$9,748,660}{\$17,500,000}\\[20pt]
2.71828^{-\text{(5r)}}&=0.5571\\[15pt]
\textbf{r}&=\boxed{0.117\space\text{or}\space11.70\%}
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, the cost of debt is 11.70%.
